title: Empirical Coordination of Separable Quantum Correlations

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We introduce the notion of empirical coordination for quantum correlations. Quantum mechanics enables the calculation of probabilities for experimental outcomes, emphasizing statistical averages rather than detailed descriptions of individual events. Empirical coordination is thus a natural framework for quantum systems. Focusing on the cascade network, the optimal coordination rates are established, indicating the minimal resources required to simulate on average a quantum state. As we consider a network with classical communication links, superposition cannot be maintained, hence the quantum correlations are separable (i.e., a convex combination of product states). This precludes entanglement. Providing the users with shared randomness, before communication begins, does not affect the optimal rates for empirical coordination. We begin with a rate characterization for a basic two-node network, and then generalize to a cascade network. The special case of a network with an isolated node is considered as well. The results can be further generalized to other networks as our analysis includes a generic achievability scheme. The optimal rate formula involves optimization over a collection of state extensions. This is a unique feature of the quantum setting, as the classical parallel does not include optimization. As demonstrated through examples, the performance depends heavily on the choice of decomposition. We further discuss the consequences of our results for quantum cooperative games.

## Index Terms

Quantum information theory, quantum communication, empirical coordination, quantum measurements, reverse Shannon theorem, separable correlations.

## I. INTRODUCTION

Recent advances in the Internet of Things (IoT) have drawn attention to the role of coordination in networks with diverse topologies [1, 2]. Cuff et al. [3] presented a general information-theoretic model for network coordination, where as opposed to traditional coding tasks, the objective is not to exchange messages between network nodes but rather generate correlation [4]. Two types of coordination tasks were introduced in the classical framework [3]. In strong coordination, the users produce actions in order to simulate a product distribution. That is, the joint distribution resembles that of a particular memoryless source [5]. Empirical coordination imposes a weaker and less stringent condition compared to strong coordination. It requires the type, i.e., the frequency of actions, to converge into a desired distribution [6]. There are many information-theoretic tasks that are closely related to coordination, such as channel/source simulation [7-12], randomness extraction [13, 14], entanglement distirbution [15], state transformation [16, 17], state merging [18, 19], entanglement dilution [20-23], and compression [24-29].

Empirical coordination and its variations are widely studied in the classical information theory literature. Le Treust [4] considered joint source-channel empirical coordination. Le Treust and Bloch [30] further used empirical coordination as a unified perspective for masking, amplification, and parameter estimation at the receiver. Cuff and Zhao [31] studied empirical coordination using implicit communication, with information embedding applications, such as digital watermarking, steganography, cooperative communication, and strategic play in team games. Cervia et al. [32] devised a polar coding scheme for empirical coordination. Related models can also be found in [33, 34].

Quantum mechanics enables the calculation of probabilities for experimental outcomes, emphasizing statistical averages rather than detailed descriptions of individual events. For instance, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that the standard deviations of position and momentum cannot be minimized simultaneously [35]. Some scholars, such as Fuchs and Peres [36], contend that the quantum theory describes physical reality at all, but is instead confined to representing statistical correlations [37]. Empirical coordination is thus a natural framework for quantum systems.

Empirical coordination also plays a role in quantum data compression [38]. The optimal compression rate for a general ensemble of mixed states is unknown [39]. Barnum et al. [40] have reformulated the model for a source of commuting density operators, and Kramer and Savari [25] developed a rate-distortion theory that unifies the visible and blind approaches (cf. [41] and [42]). Coordination of separable correlations with classical links is described as follows. Consider a network of $K$ nodes, where Node $i$ performs an encoding operation $\mathcal{E}_{i}$ on a system $A_{i}$, for $i \in[K]$. Some of the nodes are connected by one-way classical links. We denote the rate limit for the link from Node $i$ to Node $j$ by $R_{i, j}$. Before the coordination protocol begins, the nodes may also share common randomness (CR). Furthermore, some of the nodes can have access to side information. The objective in the coordination problem is to establish a specific correlation, i.e., to simulate a desired quantum state $\omega_{A_{1} \ldots A_{K}}$. Since the links are classical, the correlation is separable. The optimal performance is defined by the communication rates that are necessary and sufficient for simulating the desired correlation on average.

In analogy to the classical framework, we separate between two types of coordination tasks. In strong coordination, the users encode in order to simulate an $n$-fold product state, $\omega_{A_{1} \ldots A_{K}}^{\otimes n}$. That is, the joint state resembles that of a memoryless (i.i.d.)

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Fig. 1. Cascade network.
quantum source. In our previous work, we have considered strong coordination. In particular, we addressed strong coordination for entanglement generation using quantum links [43] and for classical-quantum (c-q) correlations with classical links [44].
Here, we introduce the notion of empirical coordination for separable correlations, imposing a weaker and less stringent condition compared to strong coordination. We require the empirical average state to converge into the desired state $\omega_{A_{1} \ldots A_{K}}$. In this work, we focus on the quantum empirical coordination of separable correlations. Our networks consist of nodes possessing quantum systems, and are connected with classical links of limited communication rates.
We define empirical coordination for quantum states, and discuss the justification for our definition and its physical interpretation. We focus on the cascade network and determine the optimal coordination rates, which represent the minimal resources for the empirical simulation of a separable state among multiple parties. The cascade setting is depicted in Figure 1. Alice, Bob, and Charlie wish to simulate a separable state $\omega_{A B C}$. They are provided with rate-limited communication links, $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ from Alice to Bob, and $R_{2 \rightarrow 3}$ from Bob to Charlie.
Our results are summarized below. We show that CR between the network users does not affect the optimal rates for empirical coordination. We begin with the rate characterization for the basic two-node network, and then generalize to a cascade network. The special case of a network with an isolated node is considered as well. The results can be further generalized to other networks as our analysis includes a generic achievability scheme. The characterization involves optimization over a collection of state extensions. This is a unique feature of the quantum setting, as the classical parallel does not include optimization [3]. As will be seen in the examples, the performance depends heavily on the choice of decomposition. We further discuss the consequences of our results for cooperative games.
In Section II, we set our notation conventions. In Section III, we present the definitions for our model and their physical interpretation. Section IV is dedicated to the results, including the statement about CR and the capacity theorems for the twonode network, the cascade network and the isolated node. Section V and Section VI provide the achievability and converse analysis, respectively. Section VII concludes with a discussion about the comparison between strong coordination and empirical coordination, as well as the implications of our results on quantum cooperative games.

# II. Notation 

We use standard notation in quantum information theory, as in [45], $X, Y, Z, \ldots$ are discrete random variables on finite alphabets $\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{Y}, \mathcal{Z}, \ldots$, respectively, The distribution of $X$ is specified by a probability mass function (PMF) $p_{X}(x)$ on $\mathcal{X}$. The set of all PMFs over $\mathcal{X}$ is denoted by $\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X})$. The normalized total variation distance between two PMFs in $\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X})$ is defined as

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left\|p_{X}-q_{X}\right\|_{1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{a \in \mathcal{X}}\left|p_{X}(a)-q_{X}(a)\right|
$$

for every $p_{X}, q_{X} \in \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X})$.
The classical Shannon entropy is then defined as $H\left(p_{X}\right)=\sum_{x \in \operatorname{supp}\left(p_{X}\right)} p_{X}(x) \log \left(\frac{1}{p_{X}(x)}\right)$, with logarithm to base 2 . We often use the short notation $H(X) \equiv H\left(p_{X}\right)$ for $X \sim p_{X}$. Similarly, given a joint PMF $p_{X Y} \in \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y})$, we write $H(X Y) \equiv H\left(p_{X Y}\right)$. The mutual information between $X$ and $Y$ is $I(X ; Y)=H(X)+H(Y)-H(X Y)$. A classical channel is defined by a probability kernel $\left\{p_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x): x \in \mathcal{X}, y \in \mathcal{Y}\right\}$. The conditional entropy with respect to $p_{X} \times p_{Y \mid X}$ is defined as $H(Y \mid X)=\sum_{x \in \operatorname{supp}\left(p_{X}\right)} p_{X}(x) H(Y \mid X=x)$, where $H(Y \mid X=x) \equiv H\left(p_{Y \mid X}(\cdot \mid x)\right)$. According to the entropy chain rule, $H(Y \mid X)=H(X Y)-H(X)$.

We use $x^{n}=\left(x_{i}: i \in[n]\right)$ for a sequence of letters from $\mathcal{X}$. We define the type of a sequence $x^{n}$ as the empirical distribution, $\hat{P}_{x^{n}}(a)=\frac{1}{a} N\left(a \mid x^{n}\right)$, where $N\left(a \mid x^{n}\right)$ is the number of occurrences of the letter $a$ in the sequence $x^{n}$, for $a \in \mathcal{X}$. The $\delta$-typical set for a PMF $p_{X}$, is defined here as the set of sequences whose type is $\delta$-close to $p_{X}$ in total variation distance. Formally,

$$
T_{\delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X}\right) \equiv\left\{x^{n} \in \mathcal{X}^{n}: \frac{1}{2}\left\|\hat{P}_{x^{n}}-p_{X}\right\|_{1}<\delta\right\}
$$

A quantum system is associated with a Hilbert space, $\mathcal{H}$. The dimensions are assumed to be finite throughout. Denote the set of all operators $F: \mathcal{H} \rightarrow \mathcal{H}$ by $L(\mathcal{H})$. The Hermitian conjugate of $F$ is denoted $F^{\dagger}$. The extension of a real-valued function

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Fig. 2. Cascade network with common randomness.
to Hermitian operators is defined in the usual manner. Analogically to the total variation distance between classical PMFs, the normalized trace distance between two Hermitian operators satisfies

$$
\frac{1}{2}\|P-Q\|_{1}=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}[|P-Q|
$$

for every Hermitian $P, Q \in L(\mathcal{H})$.
Let System $A$ be associated with $\mathcal{H}_{A}$. The quantum state of $A$ is described by a density operator $\rho_{A} \in L\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)$, i.e., a unit-trace positive semidefinite operator. Let $\Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)$ denote the set of all such operators. The probability distribution of a measurement outcome is derived from a positive operator-valued measure (POVM). In finite dimensions, this reduces to a finite set of positive semidefinite operators $\left\{D_{j}: j \in[N]\right\}$ that satisfy $\sum_{j=1}^{\mathcal{N}} D_{j}=\mathbb{1}$, where $\mathbb{1}$ denotes the identity operator. By the Born rule, the probability of a measurement outcome $j$ is given by $p_{J}(j)=\operatorname{Tr}\left(D_{j} \rho_{A}\right)$, for $j \in[N]$.
The von Neumann entropy of a quantum state $\rho_{A} \in \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)$ is defined as $H\left(\rho_{A}\right) \equiv-\operatorname{Tr}\left[\rho_{A} \log \left(\rho_{A}\right)\right]$. We often denote the quantum entropy by $H(A)_{\rho} \equiv H\left(\rho_{A}\right)$. Similarly, given a joint state $\rho_{A B} \in \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B}\right)$, we write $H(A B)_{\rho} \equiv H\left(\rho_{A B}\right)$. A pure state has zero entropy, in which case, there exists $|\psi\rangle \in \mathcal{H}_{A}$ such that $\rho=|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|$, where $\langle\psi| \equiv\langle|\psi\rangle\rangle^{\dagger}$. The conditional quantum entropy is defined by $H(A \mid B)_{\rho}=H(A B)_{\rho}-H(B)_{\rho}$. The conditional mutual information is defined accordingly, as $I(A ; B \mid C)_{\rho} \equiv H(A \mid C)_{\rho}+H(B \mid C)_{\rho}-H(A, B \mid C)_{\rho}$ for $\rho_{A B C} \in \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{C}\right)$.
A bipartite state $\rho_{A B}$ is said to be separable if a set of product states $\left\{\rho_{x} \otimes \sigma_{x}\right\}$ in $\Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B}\right)$ can be found such that

$$
\rho_{A B}=\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} p_{X}(x) \rho_{x} \otimes \sigma_{x}
$$

for some alphabet $\mathcal{X}$ and PMF $p_{X}$ on $\mathcal{X}$. Otherwise, $\rho_{A B}$ is called entangled. If the state is entangled, then the conditional entropy $H(A \mid B)_{\rho}$ can be negative. The definition can also be extended to a multipartite system. A state $\rho_{A_{1} \ldots A_{K}}$ in $\Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A_{1}} \otimes\right.$ $\left.\cdots \otimes \mathcal{H}_{A_{K}}\right)$ is said to be separable if such that

$$
\rho_{A_{1} \ldots A_{K}}=\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} p_{X}(x) \rho_{x}^{(1)} \otimes \cdots \otimes \rho_{x}^{(K)}
$$

for some ensemble $\left\{p_{X}, \rho_{x}^{(1)} \otimes \cdots \otimes \rho_{x}^{(K)}, x \in \mathcal{X}\right\}$.
A quantum channel is defined by a completely-positive trace-preserving map, $\mathcal{N}_{A \rightarrow B}: L\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right) \rightarrow L\left(\mathcal{H}_{B}\right)$. In general, the channel maps a state $\rho \in \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)$ into a state $\mathcal{N}_{A \rightarrow B}(\rho) \in \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{B}\right)$. A classical-quantum (c-q) channel $\mathcal{N}_{X \rightarrow B}$ is specified by a collection of quantum states $\left\{\rho_{B}^{(x)}: x \in \mathcal{X}\right\}$ in $\Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{B}\right)$, where $\rho_{B}^{(x)} \equiv \mathcal{N}_{X \rightarrow B}(x)$ for $x \in \mathcal{X}$.

# III. MODEL Definition and Physical Interpretation
## A. Coding definitions

In this subsection, we introduce the basic definitions for empirical coordination. Consider the cascade network shown in Figure 2, which involves three users, Alice, Bob, and Charlie. Let $\left\{p_{X}(x), \omega_{A B C}^{x}, x \in \mathcal{X}\right\}$ be a given ensemble, with an average

$$
\omega_{A B C}=\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} p_{X}(x) \omega_{A B C}^{x}
$$

Suppose that Alice receives a random sequence $X^{n}$, drawn from a memoryless (i.i.d.) source $\sim p_{X}$. This can be viewed as side information Alice obtains from a local measurement on her environment. Alice sends a classical message $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ to Bob via a noiseless link of limited rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$, and Bob sends $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}$ to Charlie at a limited rate $R_{2 \rightarrow 3}$. Next, Alice, Bob, and Charlie encode their respective quantum outputs $A^{n}, B^{n}$, and $C^{n}$. The objective of the empirical coordination protocol is for the average state to be arbitrarily close to a particular state $\omega_{A B C}$.

In other words, the users utilize a coding scheme that simulate on average a desired state $\omega_{A B C}$. We are interested in the lowest communication rates $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ that are required in order to achieve this goal.

At the beginning, we assume that Alice, Bob, and Charlie share unlimited common randomness (CR). That is, a random element $S$ is drawn a priori and distributed to Alice, Bob, and Charlie before the protocol begins. Later, we will show that CR does not affect the achievable rates.
Definition 1. A $\left(2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}, 2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}, n\right)$ empirical coordination code for the cascade network shown in Figure 2 consists of:

- a CR source $p_{S}$ over a randomization set $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$,
- a pair of classical encoding channels, $p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n} S}$ and $p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid M_{1 \rightarrow 2} S}$, over the index sets $\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right]$ and $\left[2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}\right]$, respectively, and
- c-q encoding channels,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{E}_{X S \rightarrow A}: \mathcal{X} \times \mathfrak{S}_{n} \rightarrow \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}^{\otimes n}\right) \\
& \mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow B^{n}}:\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right] \times\left[2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}\right] \times \mathfrak{S}_{n} \rightarrow \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{B}^{\otimes n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{D}_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow C^{n}}:\left[2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}\right] \times \mathfrak{S}_{n} \rightarrow \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{C}^{\otimes n}\right)
$$

for Alice, Bob, and Charlie, respectively, where $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is an unbounded set of realizations for the CR resource that is shared between the users a priori.
The protocol works as follows. Before communication begins, Alice, Bob, and Charlie share a CR element $s$, drawn from the source $p_{S}$. Alice receives a sequence $x^{n}$, generated from a memoryless source $p_{X}$. That is, the random sequence is distributed according to $p_{X}^{n}\left(x^{n}\right) \equiv \prod_{i=1}^{n} p_{X}\left(x_{i}\right)$. She selects an index

$$
m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \sim p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n} S}\left(\cdot \mid x^{n}, s\right)
$$

at random, and sends it through a noiseless classical link at rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$. She then applies the encoding channel $\mathcal{E}_{X S \rightarrow A}^{\otimes n}$, to prepare the state of her system $A^{n}$, hence

$$
\rho_{A^{n}}^{\left(x^{n}, s\right)}=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \mathcal{E}_{X S \rightarrow A}\left(x_{i}, s\right)
$$

As Bob receives the message $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ and the CR element $s$, he selects a random index

$$
m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \sim p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid M_{1 \rightarrow 2} S}\left(\cdot \mid m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, s\right)
$$

and sends it through a noiseless classical link at rate $R_{2 \rightarrow 3}$ to Charlie. Bob and Charlie encode their systems, $B^{n}$ and $C^{n}$, by

$$
\rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)}=\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow B^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)
$$

and

$$
\rho_{C^{n}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)}=\mathcal{D}_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow C^{n}}\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)
$$

respectively.
Given a value $s$, i.e., a realization of the random element, consider the average state $\bar{\rho}_{A B C}(s) \in \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{C}\right)$ that is induced by the code:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\rho}_{A B C}(s) \equiv & \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{x^{n} \in \mathcal{X}^{n}} \sum_{m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \in\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right]} \sum_{m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \in\left[2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}\right]} p_{X}^{n}\left(x^{n}\right) p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n} S}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid x^{n}, s\right) p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid M_{1 \rightarrow 2} S}\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, s\right) \\
& \cdot \rho_{A_{i}}^{\left(x_{i}, s\right)} \otimes \rho_{B_{i}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)} \otimes \rho_{C_{i}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

We now define achievable rates as rates that are sufficient in order to encode $\bar{\rho}_{A B C}(s)$ that converges to $\omega_{A B C}$.
Definition 2. A rate pair $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ is achievable for empirical coordination of a desired separable state $\omega_{A B C}$, if for every $\alpha, \varepsilon, \delta>0$ and a sufficiently large $n$, there exists a $\left(2^{n\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}+\alpha\right)}, 2^{n\left(R_{2 \rightarrow 3}+\alpha\right)}, n\right)$ coordination code that achieves

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left(\frac{1}{2}\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B C}(S)-\omega_{A B C}\right\|_{1}>\varepsilon\right) \leq \delta
$$

where the probability is computed with respect to the CR element $S \sim p_{S}$.
Equivalently, there exists a sequence of empirical coordination codes such that the error converges to zero in probability, i.e.,

$$
\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B C}(S)-\omega_{A B C}\right\|_{1} \longrightarrow 0 \text { in probability. }
$$

Remark 1. Since the communication links are classical, entanglement cannot be generated. Therefore, we only consider separable states $\omega_{A B C}$.

# B. Quantum measurements 

In this subsection, we discuss the justification and the physical interpretation of our coordination criterion. As mentioned in the Introduction, quantum mechanics enables the calculation of probabilities for experimental outcomes, emphasizing statistical averages rather than detailed descriptions of individual events. For instance, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that the standard deviations of position and momentum cannot be minimized simultaneously [35]. Some scholars, such as Fuchs and Peres [36], contend that quantum theory describe physical reality at all, but is instead confined to representing statistical correlations [37]. Empirical coordination is thus a natural framework for quantum systems. Further justification is provided below.

Consider an observable represented by an Hermitian operator $\hat{O}$ on $\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{C}$. In practice, statistics are collected by performing measurements on $n$ systems $\left(A_{i}, B_{i}, C_{i}: i \in[n]\right)$. The expected value of the observable in the $i$ th measurement is thus,

$$
\langle\hat{O}\rangle_{i}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{O} \cdot \rho_{A_{i} B_{i} C_{i}}\right]
$$

for $i \in[n]$. Therefore, the empirical average is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\langle\hat{O}\rangle_{i} & =\operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{O} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{i} B_{i} C_{i}}\right)\right] \\
& =\operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{O} \cdot \bar{\rho}_{A B C}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, consider a POVM $\left\{D_{\ell}: \ell \in[L]\right\}$ on $\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{C}$. The probability that we obtain the measurement outcome $\ell$ in the $i$ th measurement is $p_{i}(\ell)=\operatorname{Tr}\left(D_{\ell} \cdot \rho_{A_{i} B_{i} C_{i}}\right)$. Thereby, the average distribution is given by

$$
\bar{p}(\ell)=\operatorname{Tr}\left(D_{\ell} \cdot \bar{\rho}_{A B C}\right)
$$

## IV. MAIN RESULTS
## A. Common randomness does not help

Theorem 1. Any desired state $\omega_{A B C}$ that can be simulated at rate $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ through empirical coordination in the cascade network with CR assistance, can also be simulated with no CR, i.e., with $\left|\mathfrak{S}_{n}\right|=1$.

We will discuss the interpretation of this result in Subsection VII-D. The proof is provided below.
Proof. Let $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ be an achievable rate pair for empirical coordination. Consider the setting in Section III. Let the CR element $S$ and the classical side information $X^{n}$ be drawn according to $p_{S}$ and $p_{X}^{n}$, respectively. Then, Alice, Bob, and Charlie encode by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \sim p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n} S}\left(\cdot \mid x^{n}, s\right), \rho_{A^{n}}^{(x^{n}, s)}=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \mathcal{E}_{X S \rightarrow A}\left(x_{i}, s\right) \\
& m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \sim p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid M_{1 \rightarrow 2} S}\left(\cdot \mid m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, s\right), \rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)}=\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow B^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right) \\
& \rho_{C^{n}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)}=\mathcal{D}_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow C^{n}}\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Denote the normalized trace distance by

$$
d(s)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B C}(s)-\omega_{A B C}\right\|_{1}
$$

for $s \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
According to Definition 2, if a rate pair $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ is achievable, then for every $\alpha, \varepsilon, \delta>0$ and sufficiently large $n$, there exists a sequence of $\left(2^{n\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}+\alpha\right)}, 2^{n\left(R_{2 \rightarrow 3}+\alpha\right)}, n\right)$ empirical coordination codes, for which the following holds:

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left(d(S)>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right) \leq \delta
$$

Averaging over the CR element yields the following average state

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{\rho}_{A^{n} B^{n} C^{n}} & =\mathbb{E}\left[\rho_{A^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, S\right)} \otimes \rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, S\right)} \otimes \rho_{C^{n}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, S\right)}\right] \\
& =\sum_{s \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}} p_{S}(s) \rho_{A^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, s\right)} \otimes \rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, s\right)} \otimes \rho_{C^{n}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Fig. 3. Two-node network.

By the total expectation formula,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}[d(S)] & =\operatorname{Pr}\left(d(S)>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right) \cdot \mathbb{E}\left[d(S) \mid d(S)>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right]+\operatorname{Pr}\left(d(S) \leq \frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right) \cdot \mathbb{E}\left[d(S) \mid d(S) \leq \frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right] \\
& \leq \delta \cdot 1+1 \cdot \frac{\varepsilon}{2} \\
& <\varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second line follows from (25), and the last inequality holds by choosing $\delta<\frac{\varepsilon}{2}$. Therefore, there exists $s^{*} \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ for which $d\left(s^{*}\right) \leq \varepsilon$. We can thus satisfy the coordination requirement with the following encoding maps,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \sim p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n} S}\left(\cdot \mid x^{n}, s^{*}\right), \rho_{A^{n}}^{(s^{*})}=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \mathcal{E}_{X S \rightarrow A}\left(x_{i}, s^{*}\right) \\
& m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \sim p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid M_{1 \rightarrow 2} S}\left(\cdot \mid m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, s^{*}\right), \rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)}=\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow B^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s^{*}\right) \\
& \rho_{C^{n}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)}=\mathcal{D}_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} S \rightarrow C^{n}}\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}, s^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which no longer require CR.
Next, we characterize the achievable rates for empirical coordination. We begin with a basic two-node network, and then generalize to a cascade network. Based on Theorem 1 above, introducing CR does not affect the achievable rates. Therefore, we will focus our definitions on empirical coordination without CR.

# B. Two-node network 

Consider the two-node network. See Figure 3. Alice and Bob would like to simulate a separable state $\omega_{A B}$ using the scheme below. Alice receives classical side information from a memoryless source $p_{X}$. She encodes $A^{n}$, and then sends an index $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$, i.e., a classical message to Bob, at a rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$.

Formally, a $\left(2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}, n\right)$ empirical coordination code for a separable state $\omega_{A B}$ consists of an input distribution $p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n}}$ over an index set $\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right]$, a c-q encoding channel $\mathcal{E}_{X \rightarrow A}: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)$, and a c-q decoding channel $\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \rightarrow B^{n}}$. The protocol works as follows. Alice receives $x^{n}$, drawn according to $p_{X}^{n}$. She selects a random index,

$$
m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \sim p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n}}\left(\cdot \mid x^{n}\right)
$$

and sends it through a noiseless link. Furthermore, she encodes $A^{n}$ by

$$
\rho_{A^{n}}^{\left(x^{n}\right)}=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \mathcal{E}_{X \rightarrow A}\left(x_{i}\right)
$$

As Bob receives the message $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$, he prepares the state

$$
\rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)}=\mathcal{D}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \rightarrow B^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)
$$

Hence, the resulting average (joint) state is

$$
\bar{\rho}_{A B}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{x^{n} \in \mathcal{X}^{n}} \sum_{m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \in\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right]} p_{X}^{n}\left(x^{n}\right) p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid x^{n}\right) \rho_{A_{i}}^{\left(x^{n}\right)} \otimes \rho_{B_{i}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)}
$$

Definition 3. A rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2} \geq 0$ is achievable for the empirical coordination of $\omega_{A B}$, if for every $\varepsilon, \alpha>0$ and sufficiently large $n$, there exists a $\left(2^{n\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}+\alpha\right)}, n\right)$ code that achieves

$$
\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B}-\omega_{A B}\right\|_{1} \leq \varepsilon
$$

Definition 4. The empirical coordination capacity for the simulation of a separable state $\omega_{A B}$ over the two-node network is defined as the infimum of achievable rates. We denote the capacity by $C_{\text {2-node }}(\omega)$.

The optimal rate for empirical coordination is established below. Consider the extended c-q state,

$$
\omega_{X A B}=\sum_{x \in X} p_{X}(x)|x\rangle\langle x|_{X} \otimes \omega_{A B}^{x}
$$

where here, $X$ plays the role of a classical register. Furthermore, let $\mathscr{S}_{\text {2-node }}(\omega)$ be the set of all c-q extensions

$$
\sigma_{X Y A B}=\sum_{(x, y) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}} p_{X Y}(x, y)|x\rangle\langle x| \otimes|y\rangle\langle y| \otimes \sigma_{A}^{x} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y}
$$

such that

$$
\sigma_{X A B}=\omega_{X A B}
$$

Notice that given a classical pair $(X, Y)=(x, y)$, there is no correlation between $A$ and $B$. We also note that if $\omega_{A B}$ is entangled, then $\mathscr{S}_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)$ is an empty set.
Theorem 2. Let $\omega_{A B}$ be a bipartite state in $\Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B}\right)$. If the set $\mathscr{S}_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)$ is nonempty, then the empirical coordination capacity for the two-node network in Figure 3 is given by

$$
C_{\text {2-node }}(\omega)=\inf _{\sigma \in \mathscr{S}_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)} I(X ; Y)_{\sigma}
$$

Otherwise, if $\mathscr{S}_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)=\emptyset$, then coordination is impossible.
The achievability proof for Theorem 2 is given in Subsection V-B. The converse proof is provided in Subsection VI-A.
Remark 2. The set $\mathscr{S}_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)$ is empty if and only if $\omega_{A B}$ is entangled. As mentioned in Remark 1, classical links cannot generate entanglement, hence, coordination is impossible in this case.
Remark 3. The characterization involves optimization over a collection of separable states, $\mathscr{S}_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)$. This is a unique feature of the quantum setting. In the classical setting, there is no optimization. As will be seen in Examples 1 and 2, the performance depends heavily on the chosen decomposition.
Remark 4. In the special case of orthonormal sets, $\left\{\left|\sigma_{A}^{x}\right\rangle\right\}$ and $\left\{\left|\sigma_{B}^{y}\right\rangle\right\}$, the coordination capacity satisfies $C_{\text {2-node }}(\omega)=$ $I(A ; B)_{\omega}$. This case is essentially classical.
Remark 5. One may always find a decomposition of a separable state into a combination of pure states. In particular, consider

$$
\omega_{A B}=\sum_{(x, y) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}} p_{X Y}(x, y) \sigma_{A}^{x} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y}
$$

By inserting spectral decompositions,

$$
\sigma_{A}^{x}=\sum_{v_{1} \in \mathcal{V}_{1}} p_{V_{1} \mid X}\left(v_{1}|x|\left|\psi_{A}^{x, v_{1}}\right\rangle\left\langle\psi_{A}^{x, v_{1}}\right|, \sigma_{B}^{y}=\sum_{v_{2} \in \mathcal{V}_{2}} p_{V_{2} \mid Y}\left(v_{2} \mid y\right)\left|\phi_{B}^{y, v_{2}}\right\rangle\left\langle\phi_{B}^{y, v_{2}}\right|
$$

we obtain

$$
\omega_{A B}=\sum_{w_{1}, w_{2}} p_{W_{1} W_{2}}\left(w_{1}, w_{2}\right)\left|\psi_{A}^{w_{1}}\right\rangle\left\langle\psi_{A}^{w_{1}}\right| \otimes\left|\phi_{B}^{w_{2}}\right\rangle\left\langle\phi_{B}^{w_{2}}\right|
$$

where $W_{1} \equiv\left(X, V_{1}\right)$ and $W_{2} \equiv\left(Y, V_{2}\right)$. If one uses this pure-state decomposition, then the coordination rate would be $R>I\left(W_{1} ; W_{2}\right)_{\sigma}$. Nevertheless, the theorem shows that this can be suboptimal, since $I\left(X V_{1} ; Y V_{2}\right)_{\sigma} \geq I(X ; Y)_{\sigma}$.
Remark 6. Based on our previous result [44], strong coordination can be achieved at the same rate if Alice and Bob share sufficient CR before communication begins. Here, however, we assume that CR is not available to Alice and Bob. Yet, they can perform the coordination task at this rate, since the requirement of empirical coordination is less strict.
Example 1. Let $A$ and $B$ be a qubit pair, i.e., $\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)=\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{H}_{B}\right)=2$. Consider the state

$$
\omega_{A B}=\frac{1}{2}|0\rangle\langle 0| \otimes|0\rangle\langle 0|+\frac{1}{4}|1\rangle\langle 1| \otimes|0\rangle\langle 0|+\frac{1}{4}|1\rangle\langle 1| \otimes|+\rangle\langle+|
$$

where $\{|0\rangle,|1\rangle\}$ and $\{|+\rangle,|-\rangle\}$ are the computational basis and conjugate basis, respectively. Such decomposition can be associated with a joint distribution $p_{X Y}$, where $Y=X$ with probability 1 , an alphabet of size $|\mathcal{X}|=3$, and

$$
p_{X}=\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{4}, \frac{1}{4}\right)
$$

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Fig. 4. Cascade network.

Based on Theorem 2, we can achieve the rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}=I(X ; Y)_{\sigma}=1.5$. The coordination rate can be significantly improved by using the decomposition below instead,

$$
\rho_{A B}=\frac{1}{2}|0\rangle\langle 0| \otimes|0\rangle\langle 0|+\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle\langle 1| \otimes \eta
$$

where $\eta$ is the BB84 state,

$$
\eta=\frac{1}{2}|0\rangle\langle 0|+\frac{1}{2}|+\rangle\langle+|
$$

This yields the improved rate of $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}=I(X ; Y)_{\sigma}=0.3112$.
Example 2. Consider the following qubit state,

$$
\omega_{A B}=\frac{1}{2}|0\rangle\langle 0| \otimes[(1-p)|+\rangle\langle+|+p|-\rangle\langle-|]+\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle\langle 1| \otimes[p|+\rangle\langle+|+(1-p)|-\rangle\langle-|
$$

where the second qubit can be viewed as the output of a phase-flip channel, $p \in(0,1)$. In this case, we obtain

$$
I(X ; Y)_{\sigma}=1-h(p)
$$

where $h(x)=-(1-x) \log (1-x)-x \log (x)$ is the binary entropy function on $(0,1)$. For $p=\frac{1}{2}$, we have a product state $\omega_{A B}=\frac{1}{2} \otimes \frac{1}{2}$. Hence, communication is not necessary and the coordination capacity is $C_{\text {2-node }}(\omega)=0$.

# C. Cascade network 

Consider the cascade network (see Figure 4). Alice, Bob, and Charlie wish to simulate a separable state $\omega_{A B C}$ using the following scheme. Alice receives classical side information from a memoryless source $p_{X}$. She encodes $A^{n}$, and she sends an index $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$, i.e., a classical message to Bob, at a rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$. Then Bob uses the message $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ to encode his systems $B^{n}$, and sends a message $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}$ to Charlie who uses it to encode his systems $C^{n}$.

Formally, a $\left(2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}, 2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}, n\right)$ empirical coordination code for the simulation of a separable state $\omega_{A B C}$ in the cascade network consists two input distributions $p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n}}$ and $p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid X^{n} M_{1 \rightarrow 2}}$ over index sets $\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right]$ and $\left[2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}\right]$, a c-q encoding channel $\mathcal{E}_{X \rightarrow A}: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A}\right)$, and two c-q decoding channel $\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \rightarrow B^{n}}$, and $\mathcal{D}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \rightarrow C^{n}}$ The protocol works as follows.

Alice selects a random index,

$$
m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \sim p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2}}
$$

and sends it through a noiseless link. Furthermore, she encodes $A^{n}$ by

$$
\rho_{A^{n}}^{\left(x^{n}\right)}=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \mathcal{E}_{X \rightarrow A}\left(x_{i}\right)
$$

As Bob receives the message $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$, he generates $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}$ according to $p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid X^{n} M_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\left(\cdot \mid x^{n}, m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)$, sends $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}$ to Charlie, and prepares the state

$$
\rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)}=\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \rightarrow B^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)
$$

Having received the classical message $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}$, Charlie applies his c-q encoding map and prepares

$$
\rho_{C^{n}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)}=\mathcal{D}_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \rightarrow C^{n}}\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)
$$

Hence, the resulting average (joint) state is

$$
\bar{\rho}_{A B C}=\sum_{x^{n} \in X^{n}} p_{X}^{n}\left(x^{n}\right) \sum_{m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \in\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}\right]} \sum_{m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \in\left[2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}\right]} p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid x^{n}\right) p_{M_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid M_{1 \rightarrow 2} X^{n}}\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3} \mid m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, x^{n}\right)
$$

Fig. 5. Isolated node network.

$$
\cdot \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{i}}^{\left(x^{n}\right)} \otimes \rho_{B_{i}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right)} \otimes \rho_{C_{i}}^{\left(m_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)}
$$

Definition 5. A rate pair $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ is achievable for the empirical coordination of $\omega_{A B C}$ if for every $\varepsilon, \delta>0$ and a sufficiently large $n$, there exists a $\left(2^{n\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}+\delta\right)}, 2^{n\left(R_{2 \rightarrow 3}+\delta\right)}, n\right)$ code that achieves

$$
\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B C}-\omega_{A B C}\right\|_{1} \leq \varepsilon
$$

Definition 6. The empirical coordination capacity region for the simulation of a separable state $\omega_{A B C}$ over the cascade network is defined as the closure of all the achievable rate pairs $\left(R_{1,2}, R_{2,3}\right)$.

We denote the capacity region by $\mathcal{C}_{\text {Cascade }}(\omega)$.
The main result for the cascade network is established below. Consider the extended c-q state,

$$
\omega_{X A B C}=\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} p_{X}(x)|x\rangle\langle x|_{X} \otimes \omega_{A B C}^{x}
$$

Furthermore, let $\mathscr{S}_{\text {Cascade }}(\omega)$ be the set of all c-q extensions

$$
\sigma_{X Y Z A B C}=\sum_{(x, y, z) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} p_{X Y Z}(x, y, z)|x\rangle\langle x| \otimes|y\rangle\langle y| \otimes|z\rangle\langle z| \otimes \sigma_{A}^{x} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y} \otimes \sigma_{C}^{z}
$$

such that

$$
\sigma_{X A B C}=\omega_{X A B C}
$$

As before, coordination with classical links is limited to separable states (see Remarks 1 and 2).
Theorem 3. Let $\omega_{A B C}$ be a tripartite state in $\Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{C}\right)$. If the set $\mathscr{S}_{\text {Cascade }}(\omega)$ is nonempty, then the empirical coordination capacity region for the cascade network in Figure 4 is

Otherwise, if $\mathscr{S}_{\text {Cascade }}(\omega)=\emptyset$, then coordination is impossible.
The achievability proof for Theorem 3 is provided in Subsection V-C, and the converse part in Subsection VI-B.

# D. Isolated node 

Consider the isolated node network in Figure 5. This a special case of a cascade network with $R_{2 \rightarrow 3}=0$. The coordination capacity $C_{\text {Isolated }}(\omega)$ is defined similarly as in Definition 4, and can be established as a consequence of Theorem 3. Consider the extended c-q state,

$$
\omega_{X A B C}=\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} p_{X}(x)|x\rangle\langle x|_{X} \otimes \omega_{A B C}^{x}
$$

Let $\mathscr{S}_{\text {Isolated }}(\omega)$ be the set of all c-q extensions $\sigma_{X Y Z A B C}$ of the form

$$
\sigma_{X Y Z A B C}=\sum_{(x, y, z) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} p_{X Y Z}(x, y, z)|x\rangle\langle x| \otimes|y\rangle\langle y| \otimes|z\rangle\langle z| \otimes \sigma_{A}^{x} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y} \otimes \sigma_{C}^{z}
$$

such that

$$
\sigma_{X A B C}=\omega_{X A B C}
$$

and

$$
\sigma_{A C}=\sigma_{A} \otimes \sigma_{C}
$$

Corollary 4. Let $\omega_{A B C}$ be as in Theorem 3. If the set $\mathscr{S}_{\text {Isolated }}(\omega)$ is nonempty, then the empirical coordination capacity for the isolated node network in Figure 5 is given by

$$
C_{\text {Isolated }}(\omega)=\inf _{\sigma \in \mathscr{S}_{\text {Isolated }}(\omega)} I(X ; Y \mid Z)_{\sigma}
$$

Otherwise, if $\mathscr{S}_{\text {Isolated }}(\omega)=\emptyset$, then coordination is impossible.
In this case, coordination is only possible for a separable state $\omega_{A B C}$ such that $\omega_{A C}=\omega_{A} \otimes \omega_{C}$.
Remark 7. Notice that $B$ and $C$ can still be correlated. Given unlimited CR, it is clear that we may generate such a correlation. Even in the extreme case of no communication, we can generate $Y^{n}$ from a memoryless source, treat $Y^{n}$ as the CR element, and let $Z^{n}=Y^{n}$ (see discussion in [3, Sec. III-B]). We have seen that CR does not affect the coordination capacity, and thus, the same rates can be achieved without CR. Further intuition is given in the discussion in Subsection VII-D.
Example 3. Consider the following qubit state,

$$

\omega_{A B C} & =(1-\alpha)|0\rangle\left\langle\left. 0 \mid \otimes[(1-p)|+\rangle\langle+| \otimes|+\rangle\langle+|+p|-\rangle\langle-| \otimes|-\rangle\langle-|\right]\right. \\
& \left.+\alpha|1\rangle\langle 1| \otimes[(1-p)|+\rangle\langle+| \otimes|-\rangle\langle-|+p|-\rangle\langle-| \otimes|+\rangle\langle+|\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\alpha, p \in(0,1)$. In this case, $I(X ; Y \mid Z)_{\sigma}=H(X)=h(\alpha)$.

# V. ACHIEVABILITY ANALYSIS 

To show the direct part of our coordination capacity theorems, we will use the generic lemma below. Consider the generic two-node network in Figure 6, where Alice receives $x^{n}$ and $y^{n}$ as input to her encoder and encodes a quantum system $A^{n}$. Whereas, Bob receives $y^{n}$ and $z^{n}$ as input and encodes a quantum system $B^{n}$. In this case, Alice has encoding maps of the form $p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid X^{n} Y^{n} S}$ and $\mathcal{E}_{X^{n} Y^{n} S \rightarrow A^{n}}$, and Bob encodes by $\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} Y^{n} Z^{n} S \rightarrow B^{n}}$. The resulting average state is

$$
\bar{\rho}_{A B}\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}, s\right)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \in\left[2^{n} \cdot n_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right]} p_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid S}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2} \mid s\right) \rho_{A_{i}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, x^{n}, y^{n}, s\right)} \otimes \rho_{B_{i}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, y^{n}, z^{n}, s\right)}
$$

where $\rho_{A^{n}}^{\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, s\right)}=\mathcal{E}_{X^{n} Y^{n} S \rightarrow A^{n}}\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, s\right)$ and $\rho_{B^{n}}^{\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, y^{n}, z^{n}, s\right)}=\mathcal{F}_{M_{1 \rightarrow 2} Y^{n} Z^{n} S \rightarrow B^{n}}\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}, y^{n}, z^{n}, s\right)$.
Lemma 5. Consider a state ensemble, $\left\{p_{X Y Z} p_{U \mid X Y}, \sigma_{A}^{x, y} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y, z, u}\right\}$. Let

$$
\eta_{B}^{x, y, z}=\sum_{u \in \mathcal{U}} p_{U \mid X Y}(u \mid x, y) \sigma_{B}^{y, z, u}
$$

For every $\delta>0$, if

$$
R_{1 \rightarrow 2}>I(X ; U \mid Y Z)_{\sigma}+\gamma(\delta)
$$

then there exists a sequence of randomized $\left(2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}, n\right)$ empirical coordination codes such that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Pr}\left(\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B}\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}, S\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}, y_{i}} \otimes \eta_{B}^{z_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}}\right\|_{1}>\gamma(\delta)\right)=0
$$

uniformly for all $\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right) \in T_{\delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X Y Z}\right)$, where the probability is computed with respect to the CR element $S$, and $\gamma(\delta)$ tends to zero as $\delta \rightarrow 0$.

# A. Generic scheme: Achievability proof for Lemma 5 

The proof for Lemma 5 is provided below. Consider the extended c-q state,

$$
\sigma_{X Y Z U A B}=\sum_{(x, y, z, u) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z} \times \mathcal{U}} p_{X Y Z}(x, y, z) p_{U \mid X Y}(u \mid x, y)|x, y, z, u\rangle\langle x, y, z, u| \otimes \sigma_{A}^{x, y} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y, z, u}
$$

where $X, Y, Z$, and $U$ are classical registers. We note that $Z \Leftarrow(X, Y) \Leftarrow U$ forms a Markov chain.
By Theorem 1, we may assume that Alice and Bob share unlimited CR. Therefore, they can generate the codebook jointly using their random element.

Classical codebook construction: Select $2^{n R_{0}}$ sequences $u^{n}(\ell), \ell \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$, independently at random, each i.i.d. according to $p_{U}$, where

$$
p_{U}(u)=\sum_{x, y, z} p_{X Y Z}(x, y, z) p_{U \mid X Y}(u \mid x, y)
$$

Assign each sequence with a bin index $b\left(u^{n}(\ell)\right)$, where $b: \mathcal{U}^{n} \rightarrow\left[2^{n R_{1-2}}\right]$, independently at random. We thus identify the CR element $S$ as the random codebook $\left\{u^{n}(\cdot), b(\cdot)\right\}$.

Encoding: First, consider the classical encoding function $\mathcal{M}_{1 \rightarrow 2}: \mathcal{X}^{n} \times \mathcal{Y}^{n} \rightarrow\left[2^{n R_{1-2}}\right]$. Given a pair $\left(x^{n}, y^{n}\right) \in \mathcal{X}^{n} \times \mathcal{Y}^{n}$, find an index $\ell \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$ such that $\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, u^{n}(\ell)\right) \in T_{2 \delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X Y U}\right)$. If there is none, set $\ell=1$. If there is more than one, choose the smallest. Send the corresponding bin index, i.e., $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}\left(x^{n}, y^{n}\right)=b\left(u^{n}(\ell)\right)$.

Then, prepare

$$
\rho_{A^{n}}^{x^{n}, y^{n}} \equiv \bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}, y_{i}}
$$

Decoding: Given $\left(y^{n}, z^{n}\right)$ and $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}$, find an index $\hat{\ell} \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$ such that

$$
\left(y^{n}, z^{n}, u^{n}(\hat{\ell})\right) \in T_{8 \delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{Y Z U}\right) \text { and } b\left(u^{n}(\hat{\ell})\right)=m_{1 \rightarrow 2}
$$

If there is none, set $\hat{\ell}=1$. If there is more than one, choose the smallest. Prepare the state

$$
\rho_{B^{n}}^{y^{n}, z^{n}, u^{n}(\hat{\ell})} \equiv \bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{B}^{y_{i}, z_{i}, u_{i}(\hat{\ell})}
$$

This results in an average state,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\rho}_{A B}\left(u^{n}, x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right) & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{i}}^{x^{n}, y^{n}} \otimes \rho_{B_{i}}^{y^{n}, z^{n}, u^{n}} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}, y_{i}} \otimes \sigma_{B^{n}}^{y_{i}, z_{i}, u_{i}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $u^{n} \equiv u^{n}(\hat{\ell})$.
Error analysis: Given $U^{n}(\hat{\ell})=u^{n}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\rho}_{A B}\left(u^{n}, x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right) & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{(a, b, c, d) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z} \times \mathcal{U}} \sum_{i:\left(x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}, u_{i}\right)=(a, b, c, d)} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}, y_{i}} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y_{i}, z_{i}, u_{i}} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{(a, b, c, d) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z} \times \mathcal{U}} \sum_{i:\left(x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}, u_{i}\right)=(a, b, c, d)} \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{b, c, d} \\
& =\sum_{(a, b, c, d) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z} \times \mathcal{U}} \hat{P}_{x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}, u^{n}}(a, b, c, d) \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{b, c, d} \\
& =\sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} \hat{P}_{x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}}(a, b, c) \sum_{d \in \mathcal{U}} \hat{P}_{u^{n} \mid x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}}(d \mid a, b, c) \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{b, c, d}
\end{aligned}
$$

For every $u^{n}$ such that $\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}, u^{n}\right) \in T_{\gamma(\delta)}^{(n)}\left(p_{X Y Z U}\right)$,

$$
\left\|\bar{\rho}_{A B}\left(u^{n}, x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right)-\tau_{A B}\right\|_{1} \leq \gamma(\delta)
$$

where

$$
\tau_{A B}=\sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} \hat{P}_{x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}}(a, b, c) \sum_{d \in \mathcal{U}} p_{U \mid X Y Z}(d \mid a, b, c) \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{b, c, d}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} \hat{P}_{x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}}(a, b, c) \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \sum_{d \in \mathcal{U}} p_{U \mid X Y}(d \mid a, b) \sigma_{B}^{b, c, d} \\
& =\sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} \hat{P}_{x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}}(a, b, c) \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \eta_{B}^{a, b, c} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} N\left(a, b, c \mid x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right) \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \eta_{B}^{a, b, c} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} \sum_{\left.i:\left(x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}\right)=(a, b, c)\right)} \sigma_{A}^{a, b} \otimes \eta_{B}^{a, b, c} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{(a, b, c) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}} \sum_{\left.i:\left(x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}\right)=(a, b, c)\right)} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}, y_{i}} \otimes \eta_{B}^{x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}, y_{i}} \otimes \eta_{B}^{x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider the event

$$
\mathcal{A}_{1} \equiv\left\{\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}, U^{n}(\tilde{j})\right) \in T_{\gamma(\delta)}^{(n)}\left(p_{X Y Z U}\right)\right\}
$$

Based on the classical result due to Cuff et al. [3, Lemm. 14],

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left(\mathcal{A}_{1}\right) \geq 1-\alpha_{n}
$$

for all $\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right) \in T_{\delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X Y Z}\right)$, where $\gamma \equiv \gamma(\delta)$ tends to zero as $\delta \rightarrow 0$, and $\alpha_{n}$ tends to zero as $n \rightarrow \infty$, provided that

$$
R>I(X ; U \mid Y Z)+\gamma(\delta)
$$

Therefore,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left(\left\|\tilde{p}_{A B}\left(U^{n}(\hat{\ell}), x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right)-\tau_{A B}\right\|_{1}>\gamma(\delta)\right) \leq \alpha_{n}
$$

This completes the proof of Lemma 5.
We are now in a position to give the achievability proofs for the two-node and cascade networks.

# B. Two-node network: Achievability proof for Theorem 2 

The proof essentially follows from Lemma 5, with the following addition. If Alice receives a random sequence $X^{n}$ that is not $\delta$-typical, then she sends an arbitrary transmission. Otherwise, she encodes using the encoder in Lemma 5. Since $\operatorname{Pr}\left(X^{n} \in T_{\delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X}\right)\right)$ tends to 1 as $n \rightarrow \infty$, achievability for the two-node network follows.

## C. Cascade network: Achievability proof for Theorem 3

We use rate splitting, where Alice's message consists of two components $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}$ and $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}$, at rates $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}$ and $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}$, respectively, where $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}=R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}+R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}$.

Classical codebook construction: Select $2 \cdot 2^{n R_{0}}$ sequences $y^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime}\right), z^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime \prime}\right), \ell^{\prime}, \ell^{\prime \prime} \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$, independently at random, each i.i.d. according to $p_{Y}$ and $p_{Z}$, where

$$
p_{Y Z}(y, z)=\sum_{x} p_{X}(x) p_{Y Z \mid X}(y, z \mid x)
$$

Assign each sequence with a bin index $b\left(y^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime}\right)\right)$ and $c\left(z^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)$, where $b: \mathcal{Y}^{n} \rightarrow\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}}\right]$ and $c: \mathcal{Z}^{n} \rightarrow\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}}\right]$, independently at random.

Alice's encoder: As before, if Alice receives $x^{n} \notin T_{\delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X}\right)$, she sends an arbitrary transmission. Otherwise, consider the classical encoding function $\mathcal{M}_{1 \rightarrow 2}: \mathcal{X}^{n} \rightarrow\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}}\right] \times\left[2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}}\right]$ below. Given $x^{n} \in T_{\delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X}\right)$, find an index pair $\left(\ell^{\prime}, \ell^{\prime \prime}\right) \in$ $\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right] \times\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$ such that $\left(x^{n}, y^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime}\right), z^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime \prime}\right)\right) \in T_{2 \delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{X Y Z}\right)$. If there is none, set $\left(\ell^{\prime}, \ell^{\prime \prime}\right)=(1,1)$. If there is more than one, choose the first. Send the corresponding bin indices, i.e., $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}\left(x^{n}\right)=b\left(y^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime}\right)\right)$ and $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}\left(x^{n}\right)=c\left(z^{n}\left(\ell^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)$.

Then, prepare

$$
\rho_{A^{n}}^{z^{n}} \equiv \bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}}
$$

Bob's encoder: Bob receives $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}=\left(m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}, m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}\right)$, and encodes in three stages:
(i) Given $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}$, find an index $\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime} \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$ such that

$$
z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right) \in T_{8 \delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{Z}\right) \text { and } c\left(z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)=m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}
$$

If there is none, set $\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}=1$. If there is more than one, choose the smallest. Send $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}=m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}$ to Charlie.
(ii) Now given $m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}$ and $\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}$, find an index $\hat{\ell}^{\prime} \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$ such that

$$
\left(y^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime}\right), z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right) \in T_{8 \delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{Y Z}\right) \text { and } b\left(y^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime}\right)\right)=m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}
$$

If there is none, set $\hat{\ell}^{\prime}=1$. If there is more than one, choose the smallest.
(iii) Prepare the state

$$
\rho_{B^{n} \bar{Z}^{n}}^{y^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime}\right)} \equiv \bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{B}^{y_{i}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime}\right)} \otimes\left|z_{i}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right\rangle\left\langle z_{i}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right|_{\bar{Z}}
$$

where $\bar{Z}^{n}$ is an auxiary system for Bob.
Charlie's encoder: Given $m_{2 \rightarrow 3}=m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}$, find an index $\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime} \in\left[2^{n R_{0}}\right]$ such that

$$
z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right) \in T_{8 \delta}^{(n)}\left(p_{Z}\right) \text { and } c\left(z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)=m_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}
$$

If there is none, set $\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}=1$. If there is more than one, choose the smallest.
Prepare the state

$$
\rho_{C^{n}}^{z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)} \equiv \bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{C}^{z_{i}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)}
$$

This results in an average state,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\rho}_{A B \bar{Z} C}\left(x^{n}, y^{n}, z^{n}\right) & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{i}}^{z^{n}} \otimes \rho_{B_{i}}^{y^{n}} \otimes\left|\bar{z}^{n}\right\rangle\left\langle\bar{z}^{n}\right| \otimes \rho_{C_{i}}^{z^{n}} \\
& =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_{A}^{x_{i}} \otimes \sigma_{B}^{y_{i}} \otimes\left|\bar{z}_{i}\right\rangle\left\langle\bar{z}_{i}\right| \otimes \sigma_{C}^{z_{i}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $y^{n} \equiv y^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime}\right), \bar{z}^{n} \equiv z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)$, and $z^{n} \equiv z^{n}\left(\hat{\ell}^{\prime \prime}\right)$. Based on the analysis in the proof of Lemma 5 (see Section V-A), Alice, Bob, and Charlie achieve empirical coordination of $\sigma_{A B Z C}$, provided that

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{2 \rightarrow 3}= & R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}>I(X ; Z) \\
& R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}>I(X ; Y \mid Z)
\end{aligned}
$$

which requires $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}=R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime}+R_{1 \rightarrow 2}^{\prime \prime}>I(X ; Y Z)$.

# VI. CONVERSE PART ANALYSIS 

We now show the converse part for our coordination capacity theorems.

## A. Two-node network: Converse proof for Theorem 2

Consider the two-node network in Figure 3. Let $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ be an achievable rate for empirical coordination with a desired state $\omega_{A B}$. Then, there exists a sequence of $\left(2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}, n\right)$ empirical coordination codes that achieves an error,

$$
\left\|\bar{\rho}_{X A B}-\omega_{X A B}\right\|_{1} \leq \varepsilon_{n}
$$

where $\varepsilon_{n}$ tends to zero as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Now, suppose that Bob performs a projective measurement in a particular basis, say, $\{|y\rangle\}$. This yields a sequence $Y^{n}$ as the measurement outcome, with some distribution $p_{Y^{n} \mid X^{n}}\left(y^{n} \mid x^{n}\right)$.
Then, consider the classical variables $X_{J}$ and $Y_{J}$, where $J$ is a uniformly distributed random variable, over the index set $[n]$, drawn independently of $X^{n}, Y^{n}$. Their joint distribution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{p}_{X_{J} Y_{J}}(x, y) & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_{X_{i} Y_{i}}(x, y) \\
& =(\langle x| \otimes\langle y|) \bar{\rho}_{X B}(|x\rangle \otimes|y\rangle)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{X_{i} Y_{i}}$ is the marginal distribution of $p_{X}^{n} \times p_{Y^{n} \mid X^{n}}$. Based on (88), we have the following total variation bound:

$$
\left\|\bar{p}_{X_{J} Y_{J}}-\pi_{X Y}\right\|_{1} \leq \varepsilon_{n}
$$

where $\pi_{X Y}$ is defined as

$$
\pi_{X Y}(x, y)=(\langle x \mid \otimes\langle y \mid\rangle) \omega_{A B}(|x\rangle \otimes|y\rangle)
$$

for $(x, y) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}$.
Next, consider that

$$
\begin{aligned}
n R_{1 \rightarrow 2} & \geq H\left(M_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right) \\
& \geq I\left(X^{n} ; M_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right) \\
& \geq I\left(X^{n} ; Y^{n}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} I\left(X_{i} ; Y^{n} \mid X^{i-1}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} I\left(X_{i} ; X^{i-1} Y^{n}\right) \\
& \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} I\left(X_{i} ; Y_{i}\right) \\
& =n I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} \mid J\right)_{\bar{p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the third inequality holds by the data processing inequality and the following equalities by the chain rule. Since $X^{n}$ is i.i.d., it follows that $X_{J}$ and $J$ are statistically independent, hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} \mid J\right)_{\bar{p}} & =I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} J\right)_{\bar{p}} \\
& \geq I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Based on entropy continuity [46],

$$
I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}} \geq I(X ; Y)_{\pi}-\alpha_{n}
$$

where $\alpha_{n}=-3 \varepsilon_{n} \log \left(\varepsilon_{n}|\mathcal{X}||\mathcal{Y}|\right)$ [47, Lemm. 2.7], which tends to zero as $n \rightarrow \infty$. This concludes the converse proof for the two-node network.

# B. Cascade network: Converse proof for Theorem 3 

Consider the cascade network in Figure 4. If $\left(R_{1 \rightarrow 2}, R_{2 \rightarrow 3}\right)$ is achievable, then there exists a sequence of $\left(2^{n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}}, 2^{n R_{2 \rightarrow 3}}, n\right)$ codes such

$$
\left\|\bar{p}_{X A B C}-\omega_{X A B C}\right\|_{1} \leq \varepsilon_{n}
$$

where $\varepsilon_{n}$ tends to zero as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Suppose that Bob and Charlie perform projective measurements in a particular basis, say, $\{|y\rangle\}$ and $\{|z\rangle\}$, respectively. This yields a sequence $\left(Y^{n}, Z^{n}\right)$ as the measurement outcomes, with some distribution $p_{Y^{n} Z^{n} \mid X^{n}}\left(y^{n}, z^{n} \mid x^{n}\right)$.
Then, consider the classical variables $X_{J}, Y_{J}$, and $Z_{J}$, where $J$ is uniform over $[n]$, independent of $X^{n}, Y^{n}$, and $Z^{n}$. Their joint distribution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{p}_{X_{J} Y_{J} Z_{J}}(x, y, z) & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_{X_{i} Y_{i} Z_{i}}(x, y, z) \\
& =(\langle x| \otimes\langle y| \otimes\langle z|) \bar{p}_{X B C}(|x\rangle \otimes|y\rangle \otimes|z\rangle)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{X_{i} Y_{i} Z_{i}}$ is the marginal distribution of $p_{X}^{n} \times p_{Y^{n} Z^{n} \mid X^{n}}$. By (95),

$$
\left\|\bar{p}_{X_{J} Y_{J} Z_{J}}-\pi_{X Y Z}\right\|_{1} \leq \varepsilon_{n}
$$

where

$$
\pi_{X Y Z}(x, y, z)=(\langle x| \otimes\langle y| \otimes\langle z|) \omega_{A B C}(|x\rangle \otimes|y\rangle \otimes|z\rangle)
$$

for $(x, y, z) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}$.

![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Fig. 7. Encoding by Bob and Charlie.

Consider Alice's communication rate, $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$. Now, we may view the overall encoding operation of Bob and Charlie as a "black box" with $M_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ as input and $\left(B^{n}, C^{n}\right)$ as output, as shown in Figure 7. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
n R_{1 \rightarrow 2} & \geq H\left(M_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right) \\
& \geq I\left(X^{n} ; M_{1 \rightarrow 2}\right) \\
& \geq I\left(X^{n} ; Y^{n} Z^{n}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} I\left(X_{i} ; Y^{n} Z^{n} \mid X^{i-1}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} I\left(X_{i} ; X^{i-1} Y^{n} Z^{n}\right) \\
& \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} I\left(X_{i} ; Y_{i} Z_{i}\right) \\
& =n I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} Z_{J} \mid J\right)_{\bar{p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

based on the same arguments as in (92). Since $X_{J}$ and $J$ are statistically independent, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1 \rightarrow 2} & \geq I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} Z_{J} \mid J\right)_{\bar{p}} \\
& =I\left(X_{J} ; J Y_{J} Z_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}} \\
& \geq I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} Z_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Following similar steps, we also have

$$
R_{2 \rightarrow 3} \geq I\left(X_{J} ; Z_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}}
$$

Based on entropy continuity [46],

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\left(X_{J} ; Y_{J} Z_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}} & \geq I(X ; Y Z)_{\pi}-\alpha_{n} \\
I\left(X_{J} ; Z_{J}\right)_{\bar{p}} & \geq I(X ; Z)_{\pi}-\alpha_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha_{n}=-3 \varepsilon_{n} \log \left(\varepsilon_{n}|\mathcal{X}||\mathcal{Y}||\mathcal{Z}|\right)$ [47, Lemm. 2.7], which tends to zero as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

# VII. SUMMARY AND DISCUSSION
## A. Summary

We have introduced the notion of empirical coordination for quantum correlations. Quantum mechanics enables the calculation of probabilities for experimental outcomes, emphasizing statistical averages rather than detailed descriptions of individual events. Empirical coordination is thus a natural framework for quantum systems. Focusing on the cascade network, we established the optimal coordination rates, indicating the minimal resources for the empirical simulation of a quantum state. As we consider a network with classical communication links, superposition cannot be maintained, hence the quantum correlations are separable. This precludes entanglement. We have shown that providing the users with shared randomness, before communication begins, does not affect the optimal rates for empirical coordination (see Theorem 1). We began with the rate characterization for the basic two-node network (Theorem 2), and then generalized to a cascade network (Theorem 3). The special case of a network with an isolated node was addressed as well (see Corollary 4). The results generalize to other networks as our analysis includes a generic achievability scheme (see Lemma 5) . Nonetheless, we do not claim to have solved all coordination scenarios or network topologies.

Next, we discuss the consequences of our results for quantum cooperative games.

# B. Game-theoretic implications 

In many cooperative games, the payoff is associated with the correlation between the players. In the penny matching game, as introduced by Gossner et al. [48], Alice receives a classical sequence $x^{n}$ from an i.i.d source, thereafter Alice and Bob produce sequences $a^{n}$ and $b^{n}$ that should be close to one another and to $x^{n}$ as well. In other words, Alice and Bob try to guess the source sequence one bit at a time. They gain a point for every bit they both guess correctly. Alice's action $a^{n}$ is referred to as a guess, even though she knows the original source sequence $x^{n}$. As it turns out, an optimal strategy could let Alice guess wrong, i.e., $a_{i} \neq x_{i}$, for some of the time [48]. Cuff and Zhao [31] analyzed a generalized version of the game through the classical two-node network. Here, we introduce a quantum version of the game.
Suppose that Alice receives a classical sequence $x^{n}$ from an i.i.d source $p_{X}$, as depicted in the two-node network 3. The quantum encoding of each user is viewed as the actions [49]. The game is specified by a payoff map

$$
G: \Delta\left(\mathcal{H}_{A} \otimes \mathcal{H}_{B}\right) \rightarrow[0, \infty)
$$

Given a joint strategy $\omega_{A B}$, the payoff to Alice and Bob is $G\left(\omega_{A B}\right)$.
Suppose that Alice uses an empirical coordination code and send $n R_{1 \rightarrow 2}$ bits to Bob. Furthermore, let $\operatorname{SEP}(\gamma)$ be the set of all separable strategies $\omega_{A B}$ for which Alice and Bob receive a payoff $\gamma=G\left(\omega_{A B}\right)$. Alice and Bob can then reach an average payoff $\gamma \geq 0$ asymptotically, if and only if Alice can send a message to Bob at rate $R_{1 \rightarrow 2}>C_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)$ for some $\omega_{A B} \in \operatorname{SEP}(\gamma)$. The optimal rate $C_{2 \text {-node }}(\omega)$ is characterized by Theorem 2 .

## C. Strong coordination vs. empirical coordination

In analogy to the classical framework, we separate between two types of coordination tasks; strong coordination and empirical coordination.

1) Strong coordination: In the classical setting, strong coordination means that a statistician cannot reliably distinguish between the constructed sequence of actions $X_{1}^{n}, X_{2}^{n}, \ldots, X_{K}^{n}$, and random samples from the desired distribution [3]. This requires the joint distribution $p_{X_{1}^{n} X_{2}^{n} \ldots X_{K}^{n}}$ that the code induces to be arbitrarily close to the desired source $\pi \equiv \pi_{X_{1} X_{2} \ldots X_{K}}$ in total variation distance. That is, strong coordination is achieved if there exists a code sequence such that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|p_{X_{1}^{n} X_{2}^{n} \ldots X_{K}^{n}}-\pi^{n}\right\|_{1}=0
$$

where $\pi^{n}$ denotes the i.i.d. distribution corresponding to the desired source.
Consider a network of $K$ quantum nodes, where the users have access to classical communication links with limited rates $R_{i, j}$ and may share common randomness (CR) at a limited rate $R_{0}$. We say that strong coordination is achieved if there exists a code sequence such that the joint state $\rho_{A_{1}^{n} A_{2}^{n} \ldots A_{K}^{n}}$ that is the code induces converges to the desired state, i.e.,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\rho_{A_{1}^{n} A_{2}^{n} \ldots A_{K}^{n}}-\omega^{\otimes n}\right\|_{1}=0
$$

where $\omega \equiv \omega_{A_{1} A_{2} \ldots A_{K}}$ is the desired state. In our previous work [44], we have considered strong coordination for classicalquantum (c-q) correlations with classical links.
2) Empirical coordination: In the classical description, empirical coordination uses network communication in order to construct a sequence of actions that have an empirical joint distribution closely matching the desired distribution [3]. In this case, the error criterion sets a weaker requirement, given in terms of the joint type, i.e., the empirical distribution of the actions in the network. Formally, the requirement for empirical coordination is that for every $\varepsilon>0$,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Pr}\left(\left\|\hat{P}_{X_{1}^{n} X_{2}^{n} \ldots X_{K}^{n}}-\pi\right\|_{1} \geq \varepsilon\right)=0
$$

where $X_{1}^{n}, X_{2}^{n}, \ldots, X_{K}^{n}$ are the encoded actions, and the probability is computed with respect to the CR distribution.
We say that empirical coordination is achieved in a quantum coordination network if there exists a sequence of coordination codes of length $n$, such that the time-average state $\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{1, i} A_{2, i} \ldots A_{K, i}}$ that is induced by the code converges in probability to the desired source $\omega_{A_{1} A_{2} \ldots A_{K}}$, i.e.,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Pr}\left(\left\|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{1, i} A_{2, i} \ldots A_{K, i}}-\omega\right\|_{1} \geq \varepsilon\right)=0
$$

where $\omega \equiv \omega_{A_{1} A_{2} \ldots A_{K}}$ is the desired state, and the probability is computed with respect to the CR distribution. We note that the quantum definition differs in nature from the classical one (c.f. (107) and (108)).

We have discussed the justification and the physical interpretation of our coordination criterion in Subsection III-B. Consider an observable represented by an Hermitian operator $\hat{O}$ on $\mathcal{H}_{A_{1}} \otimes \cdots \mathcal{H}_{A_{K}}$. In practice, statistics are collected by performing measurements on $n$ systems $\left(A_{1, i}, \ldots, A_{K, i}: i \in[n]\right)$. The expected value of the observable in the $i$ th measurement is thus,

$$
\langle\hat{O}\rangle_{i}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{O} \cdot \rho_{A_{1, i} \ldots A_{K, i}}\right]
$$

for $i \in[n]$. Roughly speaking, our coordination criterion guarantees that the empirical average is close to the expected value with respect to a desired state, i.e.,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\langle\hat{O}\rangle_{i} & =\operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{O} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{A_{1, i} \ldots A_{K, i}}\right)\right] \\
& \approx \operatorname{Tr}\left[\hat{O} \cdot \omega_{A_{1} \ldots A_{K}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

with high probability.

# D. Common randomness does not help 

We have shown that CR does not improve the coordination capacity. That is, if $R_{\ell \sim j}$ is achievable with CR, it is also achievable without CR. We provide an intuitive explanation below. Suppose we use a coding scheme where the CR element is a sequence $U^{n}$, drawn from a memoryless source $p_{U}$ over $\mathcal{U}$, and each user encodes by a collection of maps $\left\{\mathcal{E}^{(u)}\right\}$, taking $u=U_{i}$ at time $i$. Then, this CR-assisted coding scheme can be replaced with a code based on a fixed agreed upon sequence $\tilde{u}^{n}$ of type $\tilde{P}_{\tilde{u}^{n}} \approx p_{U}$.

Since our coding scheme uses binning and not an encoder of the form $\mathcal{E}^{\left(u_{i}\right)}$, the description above is only a rough explanation to gain intuition.

## E. Applications

Recent advances in machine-to-machine communication [6] and the Internet of Things (IoT) [1] have raised interest in networks with various topologies [2]. These network topologies are relevant for various applications, such as distributed computing [50], autonomous vehicles [51], embedded sensors [52], players in a cooperative game [31], and quantum-enhanced IoT [53, 54]. Coordination with classical links is motivated by quantum-enhanced IoT networks in which the communication links are classical [53-56]. The problem at hand is to find the optimal transmission rates required in order to establish a desired correlation. Empirical coordination also plays a role in quantum data compression [38, 40, 42]. The optimal compression rate for a quantum source of pure states was first established by Schumacher [57] for a quantum source of pure states (see also [58, 59]). However, the problem remains unsolved for a general ensemble of mixed states [39]. Barnum et al. [40] have reformulated the model for a source of commuting density operators. The problem can be divided into two scenarios: in the visible scenario, the encoder has access to the entire sequence of quantum states [41], whereas in the blind scenario, the encoder only has access to a sequence of measurements but not the actual states [42]. Kramer and Savari [25] developed a rate-distortion theory that unifies those variants. Rate distortion can be viewed as a special case of empirical coordination.

## F. Future directions

In another work by the authors [43], we have also considered strong coordination in a network with quantum links. This allows for the generation of multipartite entanglement and is closely related to tasks such as quantum channel/source simulation [7-12, 60], state merging [18, 19], state redistribution [61, 62], zero-communication state transformation [16, 17], entanglement dilution [20-23], randomness extraction [13, 14], source coding [24-29], and many others. An interesting avenue for future research is to study empirical coordination in such networks. There are many other coordination scenarios and network topologies that could be studied further, e.g., empirical coordination with entanglement assistance. Other interesting directions include the one-shot setting $(n=1)$ and coordination with two-way communication.

abstract:
We introduce the notion of empirical coordination for quantum correlations.
Quantum mechanics enables the calculation of probabilities for experimental
outcomes, emphasizing statistical averages rather than detailed descriptions of
individual events. Empirical coordination is thus a natural framework for
quantum systems. Focusing on the cascade network, the optimal coordination
rates are established, indicating the minimal resources required to simulate on
average a quantum state. As we consider a network with classical communication
links, superposition cannot be maintained, hence the quantum correlations are
separable (i.e., a convex combination of product states). This precludes
entanglement. Providing the users with shared randomness, before communication
begins, does not affect the optimal rates for empirical coordination. We begin
with a rate characterization for a basic two-node network, and then generalize
to a cascade network. The special case of a network with an isolated node is
considered as well. The results can be further generalized to other networks as
our analysis includes a generic achievability scheme. The optimal rate formula
involves optimization over a collection of state extensions. This is a unique
feature of the quantum setting, as the classical parallel does not include
optimization. As demonstrated through examples, the performance depends heavily
on the choice of decomposition. We further discuss the consequences of our
results for quantum cooperative games.
